natural solution: We add three lines to the diagram, connecting midpoints of opposite edges of the hexagon: [asy] pair a=(0,0); pair b=(1,0); pair c=(2,1); pair d=(2,2); pair e=(1,2); pair f=(0,1); pair g=(1,1); pair h=(a+g)/2; pair i=(2*h+b)/3; pair j=(b+g)/2; pair k=(2*j+c)/3; pair l=(c+g)/2; pair m=(2*l+d)/3;

pair n=2*g-h; pair o=2*g-i; pair p=2*g-j; pair q=2*g-k; pair r=2*g-l; pair s=2*g-m; fill(a--b--g--cycle,gray); draw(a--b--c--d--e--f--a,black+2); draw(a--c--e--a); draw(b--d--f--b); draw(a--d); draw(b--e);

draw(c--f); draw((a+b)/2--(d+e)/2,dashed); draw((b+c)/2--(e+f)/2,dashed); draw((c+d)/2--(f+a)/2,dashed); [/asy] We have also shaded a triangle above. The shaded triangle is now divided into six regions of equal area by its medians.

In similar fashion, the whole hexagon is divided into $36$ regions of equal area. Each of the original $24$ regions covered one or two of these $36$ new regions, so the ratio of the smallest to the largest area among the original $24$ regions is $\boxed{1:2}$.

It doesn't support direct geometric calculations or computations. 

However, the concluding statement of the problem can be framed as a theorem in Isabelle, assuming that all the necessary computations have been done and the results are available. Here is how it could look:

fixes a b :: real
assumes h0 : "a = area smallest region"

shows  "a / b = 1/2"
